Expectation1: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation1: The planning session is informal, and the timeline can still shift without major impact
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: An online candidate forum for their district is streaming now.
Story: I glance at the clock, feeling the weight of two worlds pressing in. As an engineer, I’m expected to join this project planning call, to give my best estimate for the new system’s timeline. The session is informal, and I know the schedule isn’t set in stone yet, but my team relies on me to be present and thoughtful. At the same time, my phone buzzes with a reminder: the online candidate forum for my district is streaming right now. As a citizen, I believe in being informed, in listening to the candidates, and in giving feedback that could shape our community. I promised myself I’d be more engaged this election. My mind races—if I focus on the planning session, I’ll miss the live discussion and the chance to ask questions. If I tune into the forum, I’ll let my team down, maybe even set the project back. I feel torn, the expectations of both roles pulling me in opposite directions, and I can’t shake the anxiety of knowing I can’t fully meet both at once.
